llm_response.description: The retinal image shows multiple dark blotches consistent with intraretinal hemorrhages scattered throughout the fundus. There is evidence of neovascularization near the optic disc. No significant hard exudates or cotton wool spots are observed. The presence of neovascularization indicates proliferative diabetic retinopathy.

The retinal fundus image shows a clear optic disc with no signs of neovascularization. There are no visible microaneurysms, hemorrhages, exudates, or cotton wool spots. The retinal vessels appear normal without any venous beading or intraretinal microvascular abnormalities.

The retinal image shows the presence of hard exudates in the macular region. There are no visible signs of neovascularization, vitreous or preretinal hemorrhage. The optic disc appears normal, and there are no significant intraretinal hemorrhages or venous beading.

The retinal image shows multiple intraretinal hemorrhages scattered throughout the fundus, particularly in the inferior quadrant. There is no evidence of neovascularization or vitreous hemorrhage. The optic disc appears normal, and there are no signs of venous beading or intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA).

The retinal image shows signs of proliferative diabetic retinopathy. There is evidence of neovascularization, particularly around the optic disc. Additionally, there are preretinal hemorrhages visible in the inferior region of the retina. These findings are indicative of advanced diabetic retinopathy.

The retinal image shows multiple intraretinal hemorrhages, particularly in the central and lower regions. There are also signs of venous beading and possible intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA). No neovascularization or vitreous hemorrhage is observed.

The retinal fundus image shows the optic disc and surrounding retinal area. There are no visible signs of microaneurysms, hemorrhages, exudates, venous changes, or neovascularization. The retinal vessels appear normal, and there are no signs of diabetic retinopathy.

The retinal fundus image shows the presence of microaneurysms and small hemorrhages. There are also a few hard exudates visible. No signs of severe non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy such as dense or widespread intraretinal hemorrhages, venous beading, or intraretinal microvascular abnormalities are observed. Additionally, there are no signs of proliferative diabetic retinopathy such as neovascularization or vitreous/preretinal hemorrhage.

The retinal image shows multiple hard exudates scattered across the fundus, particularly in the central and left regions. There are also several microaneurysms and small dot-blot hemorrhages visible. No signs of neovascularization, vitreous hemorrhage, or significant venous beading are present.

The retinal fundus image shows multiple microaneurysms and small intraretinal hemorrhages. There are also some hard exudates present. No signs of neovascularization, vitreous hemorrhage, or significant venous beading are observed.

The retinal fundus image shows the presence of multiple hard exudates scattered around the macula. There are no signs of neovascularization, vitreous or preretinal hemorrhage. No significant venous beading or intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA) are observed. The optic disc appears normal.

The retinal fundus image shows a clear view of the optic disc and macula. There are no visible microaneurysms, hemorrhages, exudates, cotton wool spots, venous beading, intraretinal microvascular abnormalities, or neovascularization. The blood vessels appear normal without any signs of diabetic retinopathy.
